There is a remote chance (5% or less) that either Russia or the United States would officially withdraw from the INF treaty before 1 October 2018. The treaty, signed by the USSR and the U.S. in 1987 with the goal of eliminating the respective short range (500-1,000 kilometers) and intermediate range (1,000 - 5,000+ km) missiles, notably did not include provisions concerning sea-launched missiles. In other words, both sides can deploy ship or submarine-launched vectors with ranges comparable to those considered in the treaty, without violating it. Furthermore, since 2016 the Russians have permanently deployed IRBMs in their Kaliningrad Oblast (located between Poland and Lithuania), justifying the move with the need to "counterbalance" American initiatives aimed at deploying anti-ballistic missile defense systems to Europe. All considered, rescinding the treaty in the short term would serve only the political purpose of increasing the tension between the two superpowers. I deem such course of action unlikely for both Russia and the U.S., considering the current political climate on both sides.

Trump currently preoccupied with domestic issues, and hurricane Florence is likely to do significant damage and further distract Trump interests. Russia unlikely to pull out due to the risk of sanctions. There is also an international taboo when it comes to nuclear capabilities.

The 1 October 2018 deadline and the stipulation for an announcement makes me think this leans towards unlikely. The 2019 National Defense Authorization Act which allows research into INF prohibited systems illustrates a willingness to step up to the line.

Russia’s precedent for “suspending” treaties with the US—set in 2007 when it suspended its implementation of the Conventional Forces in Europe—and the US’s recent answer in the 2019 National Defense Authorization Act, which includes provisions that allow the US to “suspend” its implementation of the INF Treaty in response to a violation by Russia, open the door for this type of action. However, President Trump wants to continue trying to improve relations with Russia, and suspending or withdrawing from the treaty would be antithetical to that goal. It also provides little benefit for the US when other types of weapons factor much more prominently today than Cold War-era ballistic missiles. President Putin is already taking aggressive steps in other domains (i.e., annexation of Crimea, 2016 US election meddling) that have been exposed and have resulted in further sanctions and indictments against Russians. Therefore, he also is unlikely to take such a provocative step as openly suspending or withdrawing from the treaty when Russia has relatively little to gain from such an action.

Highly unlikely Considerations:
Action by Russia - Russia already violates terms off the treaty with little to no repercussions. Scrapping the treaty only makes sense for Russia if there will be a following increase production of intermediate-Range capability. Russia does not have the economic strength to justify such an increase in military expenditures. Increasing Russia's capability for intermediate range missiles doesn't address tactical requirements in Ukraine or Syria. Presidential elections were recently held in March 2018 so there will be little need for Vladimir Putin to make this type of move as a political statement.  Action by the United States - The 2019 National Defense Authorization Act includes provisions that require President Trump to determine whether Russia is in violation of the treaty and whether the treaty prohibitions continue to apply to the United States. The 2019 NDAA creates a program to develop and test a new missile system that would be in violation of the treaty. Taken out of current political context, it would certainly seem that the US was moving towards suspending participation if not outright withdrawing from the treaty. However, given the short time left, the focus of the American political consciousness on the mid-term elections, and recent allegations of internal division within the Trump administration, it is extremely unlikely that the administration or congress would take such a high-profile step as withdrawing from a nuclear arms control treaty before 1 October.

It is unlikely that either Russia or the United States will announce that it is suspending its participation in or withdrawing from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty  before 1 October 2018.  In the Secretary General's 2017 Report, NATO affirmed, "The Treaty has contributed to strategic stability and reduced the risk of miscalculation leading to conflict. The Alliance is committed to the preservation of the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty and strongly believes full compliance with this landmark arms control treaty is needed. In December 2017, NATO recognised the United States’ compliance with its obligations under the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty and its commitment to implementing the Treaty. The Alliance also welcomed the continued efforts by the United States to engage Russia to resolve concerns about Russia’s compliance with the Treaty" (https://www.nato.int/nato_static_fl2014/assets/pdf/pdf_2018_03/20180315_SG_AnnualReport_en.pdf). Furthermore, both Russia and the United States have long accused each other of violating the treaty, and in February 2018, the Trump administration "proposed development of a new nuclear-armed sea-launched cruise missile, which U.S. defense leaders have also suggested might entice Russia to come back into compliance (https://www.cfr.org/backgrounder/uncertain-future-inf-treaty).  While relations between Russia and the United States are becoming increasingly hostile, there is no evidence that either country is looking to engage in another nuclear arms race. “The treaty limited only ABMs capable of defending against strategic ballistic missiles, without attempting to define strategic. Neither country intended to stop the development of counter-tactical ABMs. The topic became disputable as soon as more potent counter-tactical ABMs started to be capable of shooting down SLBMs, nevertheless both sides continued counter tactical ABM development” 
“March 23, 1983 President Reagan announced the Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI), a research program into ballistic missile defence which would be “consistent with our obligations under the ABM Treaty” - sounds similar to the recent statement made in the NPR: “the United States is commencing INF-Treaty compliant research and development by reviewing military concepts and options for conventional, ground-launched, intermediate range missile systems.

“In 1987, the USSR withdrew its opposition, concluding the SDI posed no threat and scientifically “would never work”

Since the end of the Cold War, the INF treaty has encouraged both the US and Russia to make progress on reducing their nuclear forces and is held in great regard by both sides. Due to its success, like any other treaty, both sides will try to maintain participation into the treaty until all other options are exhausted. Despite the recent perceived violations by Russia in its testing of the 9M729, it is still not a substantial attack for the treaty and there are still options left to bring Russia back into compliance. Among the most important of these options is the Special Verification Commission. Recently, Russia has criticized the United States  in its deployment of the Aegis Ashore launchers, by stating that the United States was in breach of the treaty as the launchers could carry prohibited missiles. The Commission could work by allowing inspectors to view both weapons and determine their capabilities, which would be a great sign of mutual respect. In addition, the US could pressure its allies into ensuring that the INF treaty remains a top priority on their agenda in their discussions with delegates of Russia. In summation, long term successful treaties are usually held until all options are exhausted, and the INF treaty should be no different as both sides have options for resolving disputes.

The challenge question for this week is: “Before 1 October 2018, will either Russia or the United States announce that it is suspending its participation in or withdrawing from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty?”  I am forecasting that there is a 10% probability that either Russia or the US will suspend its participation in or withdraw from the INF Treaty.  Since the treaty’s signing in 1987 by Reagan and Gorbachev, the treaty has been responsible for a fair portion of nuclear capability disarmament, such as banning ground-launched ballistic and cruise missiles with ranges between 300 and 3,300 miles.  As a result, 2,700 missiles and launchers have been destroyed by both countries.  Recent developments have made it more difficult for either country to remain committed to the treaty’s premise.  Russia has violated the treaty by deploying a prohibited ground-launched cruise missile.  This action violates the treaty’s prohibitions on producing, flight-testing, and possessing intermediate-range ground-launched missile. From its conception, the INF's value was as much (if not more) symbolic than it was strategic. It did not serve to fully eliminate the ability of either the US or Russia to strike any given target on the planet with some form of nuclear weapon. Long range ICBMs, sea-based vehicles, and strategic bombers could still allow for this capability. As such the value in the INF was largely as a symbolic agreement continuing a (somewhat disingenuous) trend toward disarmament as well as a cost saving measure for both parties. If one is faced with evaluating the likelihood of either party suspending the agreement, the first step is to assess what would be gained. In my estimation, just as the value in entering it was largely symbolic, the main possibilities for leaving it would also be based in some type of symbolism. The United States has a president and congress who may increasingly find themselves in a position where appearing to be strong in opposition to Russia on anything will be politically useful. Additionally, Russia has grown increasingly brazen in its willingness to break international agreements and understandings without any realistic expectation of rebuke. As such a US suspension of the INF could serve as a means for the US administration/congress to  appear to be anti-Russia and publicly admonish Russian aggressive behavior in context that is not likely to be particularly impactful. 
Both have implemented programs that are fundamental violations of the INF, if not in its wording in its spirit. Given that there has, to this point, been no repudiation for these violations, it is hard to see that there is any great strategic value in leaving the INF. For this reason as well as the fact that most observers (in the US particularly) don't rate the INF high on their list of important international agreements, making it weak as a symbolic token of defiance against Russia make it less likely to be used in this manner. The wild card nature of President Trump forces one to increase any assessment of what is remotely possible though which is why I made this outcome as likely as I did.

1. The utility of the INF Treaty as it currently exists: missile technology has advanced significantly since 1987 such that the subsection of weapons it was designed to prohibit (approximately 500-1000km) can now be launched by other means not explicitly covered by the INF treaty - namely by sea. If the current canvas of missile capabilities can be launched in ways that bypass the INF treaty, one would then have to consider the principle strength of the INF Treaty to be the fact that it reflects a moment of solidarity in time rather than a functional agreement that limits certain types of missiles.  2. Principles of plausible deniability: It is likely that Russia and the United States accept a certain amount of non-compliance with arms treaties because providing demonstrable proof of the existence of arms that violate the treaty would possibly also reveal sources and methods of intelligence collection both nations would prefer to preserve. This implies that the treaty itself could be rotten at its core, which further reinforces the idea that the principle strength of the treaty is its political significance.  3. The results of the Russian collusion investigation in the United States. Should the Robert Mueller investigation progress or escalate to a point of concluding that there was collusion between the Trump Administration and the Kremlin, it's possible that the Trump Administration would publicly walk away from the agreement as a method of distancing itself from Russia.  If one assumes that the INF Treaty is more of a "dinosaur" in the current age of weapon technology, then its strength is in its political weight. While heavy, there are reasonable futures where it could become collateral in a political effort to publicly signal separation between the US from Russia. Alternatively, the treaty might be so broken that the political step of walking away from the agreement would simply be unnecessary.
